column10: b'b" __get() can\'t recursively call itself"'
b"b'   hphp output:HipHop Notice: Undefined property: foo::$barphp output:bar'"

b'b" Here\'s a much smaller script to demonstrate this issue: class foo {  function __get($v)  {  switch($v) {  case \'foo\':  return $this->bar;  break;  case \'bar\':  return \'bar\';  break;  }  }  } $foo = new foo();echo($foo->foo); hphpi output:HipHop Notice:  Undefined property: foo::$barphp output:bar"'

b'b" The problem appears to be that in .  The UseGet attribute does not take into account the name of the __get() attribute that are you fetching.  It seems like in order to fix this you\'d have to keep a stack of attributes that you are running __get() on which could be a major performance hit."'

column10: b"b' PDOStatement->rowCount() always return 0'"
b"b' Hallo
column11: Using PDOStatement->rowCount() always returns 0 even if there have been affected rows by the queries i tested!I didnt found an issue about that already in the database so I just post it right now! This is really an importand feature for insane checks when operating with money or related data! RegardsAndreas'"

column10: b'b" In HPHP
column11: PDO queries are unbuffered by default
column12: which mean that the PDO driver can\'t know how many rows will be returned until they\'re all fetched.  There are a few ways to deal with this either use bufffered queries; include a statement to count how many rows would be returned (e.g. FOUND_ROWS() )
column13: or fetch everything first with fetchAll() and count the results. url  This actually a common problem on other DBs as well
column14: like MSSQL
column15: where it\'s common to use NOCOUNT to prevent the expense of counting rows you might not use. Btw
column16: I\'m assuming you\'re talking about SELECT statements as opposed to  statements."'

column11: I\'ve had a problem linking with libhphp_runtime.a. The symptom is that libhphp_runtime.a doesn\'t end up with all the symbols that it should and I get undefined errors later in the build when executables try to link with the library. I\'m not a cmake expert
column12: but I\'ve tracked it down to .  After running cmake in a clean directory
column13: my (Ubuntu 11.10)  looks like:/ cr ../  (objects)/ r  ../  (more objects)/ ../ I can fix it by merging the two ar lines into one so that it now looks like:/ cr ../  (objects) (more objects)/ ../ After that the build finishes."'

column10: b'b" ar resolves based on filename
column11: when it sees a filename twice it overwrites it. There are two  I think. The solution is to sort the files in . I\'ve not yet had time to write this so I\'ve been manually fixing it like you have."'

column10: b'b\' victorbfs
column11: Scripts like/ cr ../ (objects)/ r ../ (more objects) are generated automatically by cmake utility. I dont know why the script is divided to two or more strings
column12: but I suppose that there are some internal limits for the length of the script
column13: or smth like this. "cr" means that the lib libhphp_runtime.a will be re-created even if exists
column14: and objects are added with replacement (if such object already exists
column15: it will be replaced). "r" the lib is not re-created
column16: objects are just added with replacement. And I dont know why
column17: but the object is replaced if its name (not path + name!) is the same with another object path. E.g.:/ cr ../ /path1/Obj/ r ../ /path2/Objwill be replaced. But in case:  / cr ../ /path1/Obj /path2/Objwont be replaced
column18: if it\\\'s all written in one string command. UsingSET(CMAKE_CXX_ARCHIVE_APPEND " q ")you say that you want to use directive "q" for appending objects. And you will get in this case:/ cr ../ (objects)/ q ../ (more objects) q is Quick append
column19: without checking for replacement. Details are here:url \''

column10: b"b' Disable hardware counters on linux'"
b'b" How to disable hardware counters on Linux
column11: cause old kernels dosen\'t support hardware counters;  /hiphop-:86: undefined reference to  HPHP::Util::HardwareCounter::SetPerfEvents(HPHP::String const&)\':  /hiphop-:94: undefined reference to "'

column10: b'b" Funnily enough
column11: I recently added the ability to disable hardware counters because non-linux platforms would (of course) fail to build with them. I\'ll look into making a test so that they\'re automatically disabled on older kernels like yours
column12: but in the mean time
column13: you can get your build going by editing  and looking for this section: # Disable hardware counters off of Linux if(NOT LINUX)    add_definitions(-DNO_HARDWARE_COUNTERS)    list(REMOVE_ITEM CXX_SOURCES ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/)endif() Just comment out (or remove) the if() and endif() lines so that the define is always set and the source file is always removed from the make target."'

b"b' Additional note
column11: any driver solution
column12: really needs to support the same interface as the offucial 10gen php driver. Currently that is the only game in town
column13: so virtualy all existing packages
column14: libraries
column15: frameworks etc
column16: which are a large and fast growing body of code
column17: expects to interact with mongo using the same classes and interfaces. This is analogous to the mysql interface in hhvm
column18: adding a non php complient mysql interface to hhvm would have been a non-starter
column19: and would have significantly impacted takeup. Mongodb is now in the same position. An initial subset of key features may be acceptable
column20: with inactive stubs for unsupported calls
column21: as the interface is rich and has many low usage features
column22: but a different incompatable interface would of limited utility.'"

column10: b'b\' 10gen have unified all thier drivers as being layers ontop of thier "c"driver and "bson" driver. The low level drivers are useable from both php7and hhvm. There is a second layer called the "php library" which is writtenin pure php and sits ontop of the new low level driver which provide asclose as possible emulation of tbe legacy php driver. As you have noted i linked to the php driver
column11: you are correct in that thereis a seperate hhvm version that you linked to. But they both use the sameuserland php-library. Its all very confusing and 10gen have been very bad at commicating what isgoing on. But essential you are correct the php driver stack now consistes of 4components1. Low level driver for mongo and bson for "c"2. Lowlevel driver for php 5.5+ and php7 that sits ontop of 1.3. Lowlevel driver for hhvm that sits ontop of 14. Php driver library in php that sits ontop of 2 or 3. On Thu

b"b' Problem with spl_autoload_register'"

b"b' I think I just figured out what is the reason behind the problem with spl_autoload_register that I briefly described here: url  PHP call to spl_autoload_register is translated to C++ call to AutoloadHandler::addHandler () and that one figures out signature of the passed autoload function by calling getSignature which returns the same string for both cases from my example. Signature is used as a key in m_handlers which is a map of all handlers
column11: so when this code is executed: ... it removes previously registered handler and adds the new one (replace).'"

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: told you it\'d be something deceptively simple.  Give this a shot?  "'

b"b' -x64.h:362:20: error: uninitialized const \\xe2\\x80\\x98HPHP::VM::Transl::reg::rip\\xe2\\x80\\x99 [-fpermissive]-x64.h:133:8: note: \\xe2\\x80\\x98const struct HPHP::VM::Transl::RegRIP\\xe2\\x80\\x99 has no user-provided default constructor use gcc 4.6.1 on a non-standard dirboost_1_50_0rhel 6.2'"

b"b' ok
column11: gcc 4.6.1 will disallow init a const object without default constructor. just add a cxxflags to resolve this issue.in
column12: add -fpermissive  just after -std=gnu++0x/'"

column11: $value) {   $this->values[$var] = $value; }  function subrender() {  echo \\\'sub: \\\'.$this->foo."\\\\r\\\\n"; }  }  class b extends a {  }  $test = new  b(); $test->foo = \\\'lol\\\'; $test->render(); $test->subrender(); ?Expected result:render: lolsub:lol hhvm Without Jitrender: lolsub: lol hhvm With Jit:render: sub: lol The property foo remains like in cache in the object
column12: it is not correctly accessible using $this ($this->foo doesn\\\'t call parent::__get)\''

column10: b'b" Thanks for reporting this issue! We\'ve been tracking this inconsistency and hope to fix it soon. While conforming to the standard PHP semantics is an important goal for us

column11: where  is:   Using this micro-benchmark: Output from (expecting JIT)  Output using (using JIT) Output with JIT off via cli using (JIT disabled)  '"

column10: b'b" This was asked on StackOverflow recently
column11: possibly by you -either way
column12: reposting the answer from there: HHVM engineer here. In server mode
column13: HHVM will run the first N requests it sees in interpreter-only mode (i.e. with the JIT off). The default in an optimized build is N=11
column14: so if you were to run the request 12 times
column15: the 12th one would be much faster. You can tune this with a config option
column16: like so: -v =3. If you set it to 0
column17: you\'ll see the speedup immediately. There are a couple reasons to do this. First
column18: it prevents transient warmup effects from affecting JIT-compiled code. For example
column19: the first few requests may need populate values in APC
column20: which will cause the application code to go down different paths from the steady-state paths. This way
column21: we don\'t waste space on JIT compilations that will only be used a few times. Second
column22: it allows HHVM to collect profiling information to improve future compilation. If we observe that a certain value is an integer 99% of the time
column24: we can compile code that\'s optimized for the integer case. We currently don\'t have the facility to JIT-compile code with profiling enabled (the hard part is safely throwing it away once we\'re done with it)
column25: so we do the data collection in interpreter-only mode."'

column12: 1<<22).Run the test case with hhvm no-config. The bug is inherently allocator-dependent

b'b\' As a note about "register_postsend_function" which may make it APPEAR to no instantly close the browser session even thought it actually is. HHVM has a limited number of worker threads to process requests. Even though the browser connection is closed
column11: the worker thread is still actively processing the request. On my particular HHVM test instance
column12: there are a total of 4 worker threads. Doing the example above with "Sleep(10)" (taking 10 seconds of execution time) First through fourth request returns instantly.Request #5 then stalls waiting for there to be an active worker thread. This means that it is stalling BEFORE execution even begins at the first line of  code
column13: NOT stalling at "register_postsend_function"\''

column10: b'b" (CC @oyamauchi as the resident NameValueTableWrapper / $GLOBALS expert) ASAN doesn\'t seem to have helped here
column11: thanks for trying that. 1)Re:
column12: you shouldn\'t need to do that. What version of libdwarf do you have? is bound to in both the OS X and Linux versions [and g_dwarfCallback matches that] I\'m looking at so I\'m confused as to what is going on as it\'s trying to cast it to a  . Can you share your libdwarf.h in a gist? I doubt this is what is causing the problem you are seeing but there\'s something wrong here too. 2)For some reason the global appears to be based on the second frame. I wonder if something is overwriting it? Is this being called during  some other weird time? [It doesn\'t look like it from the stack.] Do you have any PHP or custom extension code that modifies $GLOBALS? This variable is thread-local so even if you had parallelized reads it shouldn\'t be clobbering it. It might be worth setting a watchpoint on that global variable value and watch how it changes -something appears to be setting to to null. (It would admittedly be easier for us to do this in house but we haven\'t seen this internally.)"'

b'b" I just went through my code. The only place where I use new operator is FastCGIAcceptor::onNewConnection. From my brief looking through it it seems that I shouldn\'t use it there and instead pass an address to a stack variable. The object under the pointer is copied inside ConnectionManager and in fact never gets freed. I will try that tomorrow. You can also try patching it yourself and see if it solves the issue. I am available on the #hhvm irc channel under alias julk if you need further instructions on how to do that."'
b'b" Hmm
column11: tested
column12: but it\'s definitely not that. Turns out ConnectionManager uses an intrusive list to store connections so it in fact owns the pointers passed in."'

b"b' Magic Methods cannot be called recursively'"
b'b\' Issue for #1014  This is an issue for several major pieces of PHP code in the wild. For reference
column11: the PHP behaviour allows calls to magic methods to recurse as long as there isn\\\'t an identical call on the stack
column12: this means you can still trigger a magic method from within a magic method as long as the call itself is different. In Zend this outputs In HHVM
column13: this only  s "foo" and then fatals on  .\''

column10: b"b' Duping this out for #1014.'"
b'b" This is actually the only issue open for this at the moment
column11: nevermind. @paroski had stated he wanted to fix this and had some ideas but I\'m not sure if he\'s still intending to work on it. #384 has the most complete discussion of why this is nontrivial -we are aware of it
column12: we just haven\'t gotten to it yet."'

column10: b'b" The behaviour described in #384 is not _quite_ accurate. Looking at the Zend implementation
column11: it uses a guard for the property name on the object
column12: but has flags for whether it\'s in a set
column13: get
column14: isset etc all separately. This means that setting a property from within a will still call
column15: it only prevents infinite recursion
column16: so each magic property method is treated separately. Otherwise
column17: the triviality of it depends on whether adding another field to is acceptable or not. I do understand that is a very performance critical piece of code
column18: so it may very well be unacceptable
column19: in which case the solution is much more complex. Unfortunately
column20: there is code that relies on the ability to use magic property methods from within an existing magic property call
column21: though I haven\'t seen any that rely on the fact that from within a magic method has different behaviour than outside of it."'

column10: b"b' A common pattern for its use is as follows so it is easy to make any property dynamic
column11: just remove the property and replace it with calc_...  it works everywhere. ZEND PHP tries to prevent infinite recursion by returning null for __get when it is called for the SAME property again from __get method. Infinite recursion is a bug in any case and just returning wrong result in this case is a bad option actually. Would be much better to let it run out of stack and give error than to hide it and return a wrong result as ZEND PHP does right now. So why not just enable the recursive __get without any limitations? Cant really see any code that would fail in this case that is not already failing now (where now recursive __get is disabled alltogether). I think that recursive __get and __set are a big part of PHP and much code depends on it (atleast our code does). And some libraries just wont run under hhvm. If limitless recursive __get would give someone a probem
column12: then it is very easy do add recursion blocker in their __get method
column13: whereis currenty we would need to rewrite entire libraries.  So any reason why not just enable the recursive __get without any limitations (should be better than current solution )?'"

column10: b'b" Because it isn\'t the same behaviour. There are actually different semantics based on a variety of factors that means that code that could be infinitely recursive is actually valid. "'
b"b' @jdelong is actively working on this.'"
b'b\' If there is some code that relies on PHP returning null if the same property is acessed inside itself
column11: then it is very easy to manually write few lines of PHP code inside the __get function to mimic ZEND behaviour. Actually it might not be too hard to write into HHVM. The __anti_loop array can be first initialized when first recursion occurs. It would look perhaps something like this: Right now HHVM is keeping track if the execution is inside a magick method and refuses to call another magick method. Instead of refusing it should just call another function lets say "__get_from_inside_a_magick_method" that initialyzes the anti loop functionality. It could actually be a static internal HHVM C method (my PHP code is just for illustration for the idea) That would mean that as long as a magick method is not used recursivly the code would run exactly as fast as right now and use same amount of memory. The recursive magick method calls would be a bit slower and require more memory however it so much better than not having the feature at all. Seems to me an easy solution. Or what do others think? Btw
column12: did some tests on my code
column13: HHVM runs 4 times faster on it and uses 5 times less memoryAmazing work guys
column14: thank you!. To: scannellSuper
column15: thanks!\''

column10: b"b' @mlaak the method you propose is the one that PHP uses
column11: however
column12: it requires an extra field on all objects. Given that objects are very performance sensitive
column13: adding an extra field may not be acceptable. This is why the solution is not actually as easy as it first seems.'"

column10: b'b" It\'ll probably be a day or two before it\'s in the OSS repo
column11: but I have a fix that doesn\'t involve adding a field to all objects.  (It costs a few stores to thread local storage whenever you enter a magic property method
column12: and only costs more when they are actually invoked recursively.) I\'m a little inclined to agree with @mlaak that it would probably be nicer if the recursion was just allowed completely unchecked
column13: but PHP does what it does
column14: so we\'ll try to match it ;)"'

column10: b'b" fyi
column11: i found a smaller repro (it\'s in my pull request fixing this issue). the issue only seems to come up when a method from an interface is implemented as final by class A and an abstract subclass B of A explicitly declares it is reimplementing the interface. in this case the method for B and all children will not report itself as final in ReflectionMethod."'

column10: b"b' Zend incompatibility: string casting a ReflectionParameter does not produce the expected result'"
b"b' As Reflection throws an exception when trying to get the typehinted class of a ReflectionParameter if it does not exist (because of a missing optional dependency for instance)
column11: mocking libraries currently have 2 choices to handle this case:ignore the typehint (done in PHPUnit_MockObject)
column12: which produces a broken mock class (incompatible signature in the overwritten method)infer the typehint from the string representation of ReflectionParameter (done in [Prophecy]url  thanks to the way it works in Zend: url  However
column13: when trying to run Prophecy on HHVM
column14: I discovered that HHVM does not produce this string representation: url '"

column10: b"b' Thanks for reporting this. @simonwelsh
column11: any ideas? (I know you were in the rewrite process before the conversion.)'"

column10: b"b' Well
column11: looking at the code
column12: the string representations are indeed not yet implemented in Reflection: url '"

column10: b"b' I believe we have an internal task for someone to implement the Reflection*::_toString functions: cc: @fredemmott '"
b"b' Just for reference
column11: reading the source code of HHVM allowed me to found a way to fix Prophecy thanks to a HHVM-specific method in ReflectionParameter: url Having this method in Zend would actually have made the work far simpler for mocking libraries :)'"

b'b" Planned; they\'re lower priority than the ReflectionParameter implementation as it doesn\'t seem that common frameworks depend on them."'

column10: b"b' date_create() function inconsistency'"

b'b" The date_create() function url  allows passing null as the first argument to use the current time. hhvm does not seem to support this and the function returns false. The following demo script shows this: Below is what should happen when the script is run from php: and with hhvm: I\'m running this on an Ubuntu 12.04 server with the following versions:   The use case for this feature if you\'re interested is the following line in one of WordPress\' core files (wpline 127): This returning false then goes on to cause code later down the line to fatal. Changing null to \'now\' does actually fix this but as it\'s in the WordPress core and documented to work differently on  this should be fixed on the hhvm side imo. Let me know if you need any more info :)"'

b'b\' I reported this issue to @ptarjan on IRC he fixed it (he said it was a 1 liner). It\\\'ll make it into 2.4.1 but it\\\'s not clear when this get\\\'s released. You can use the nightly build (he said it\\\'ll probally be in the one on monday or tuesday). In Wordpress there are 4 more usages (in 3 files). You can fix it (for now) with replacing it with "new DateTime()" (which date_create() is a alias for). Of course you have to fix this everytime Wordpress updates its files. But I expect HHVM 2.4.1 before WP 3.8.2 (hopefully).\''
b"b' Perfect
column11: thanks for letting him know and @ptarjan for fixing it :+1: I can just patch WordPress for now.'"

column10: b'b\' Having the problem with duplicate values in post. ##### My setup  OS: HHVM:  NGINX: ##### My form ##### Result On my computer i consistently get duplicates when selecting 4 or more options. The problem goes away when i remove enctype="-data" from the form tag. We tried the same example on a co-worker\\\'s computer and he did not get this problem. The main difference between our setups is that he is running hhvm and nginx inside a docker container localy on Ubuntu 14.04. He\\\'s HHVM version 3.9.1 and Nginx 1.9.7. We have had this problem on different sites for about a year on different HHVM versions
column11: so I don\\\'t think it related to specific versions. We noticed that if you post different combinations of form data you can get rid of the duplicates
column12: and this can be different combinations of form data when running on different computers.\''

column10: b'b\' I can confirm this problem.We have been running HHVM in production environment for about a year now. We are mostly running Magento sites. Our setup varies
column11: we have servers running nginx / hhvm and lighttpd / hhvm. All of them use fastcgi and Ubuntu server 14.04. The error occurs on both lighttpd and nginx.It is not connected to a specific HHVM version. We have seen this error since we started using HHVM (don\\\'t remember the version) a year ago until the latest version
column12: 3.10.1. I have only seen this error occur on forms using the enctype="-data" property. In Magento there are some pages that first sends the data as an url encoded post (via ajax
column13: for validation) and then sends the same data as -data for saving. The error never occurs on the first post (url encoded). I have only seen the duplicate data on checkbox and multiselect inputs
column14: which all have in common that their name ends with []
column15: like or  . It seems like the process environment on the server is affecting the error (race condition?
column16: cache problem?). It comes and goes
column17: it happens on one server but not the other. Upgrading
column18: restarting sometimes makes it go away
column19: sometimes makes it come back.However
column20: once it is there
column21: it is quite persistent until you restart or upgrade something. Also changing the form data can affect it. We are using this workaround in Magento:If the problem occurs
column22: select a different option
column24: select the correct option and save again. It works most of the time. I hope this helps.\''

column10: b"b' Thanks for reporting this. Feel free to submit a PR if you (or someone else reading this) gets to this before we do.'"
b"b'   is not a security feature. Please see url  for more information.'"
b'b\' The security aspect is totally valid and postulating it as a security mechanism is a farce. However
column11: using chroot as a "performance mechanism" can make sense in some cases to squeeze out the last percent of the system. What do I mean by that. If your disk is kinda slow
column12: you can save a lot of stat() calls when you encounter a lot of includes and very long paths. I discovered this when I implemented some new features on PHP ( url  ). APC in the PHP world only helped when stat calls were completely turned off.\''

column10: b"b' Closing as WONTFIX. Slow disk is covered by inotify to reduce useless stats calls as well as repo mode.'"

b"b' I prefere to use the php-fpm chroot feature because it hardens the web installation (that is also stated by the page that LiraNuna linked). A php-fpm chroot installation can be so minimal that it offers only very minimal libraries
column11: no headers and (if you want) no command line tools for the attackers to work with. It also **does not need /proc and /dev**
column12: which means that it hides critical systeminformations like running processes
column13: config files and logged in users. That IS a feature
column14: as this prevents  local root exploits found in the wild to work
column15: and without root they cant break out. It may be true that a genious hacker still can work around all that
column16: but all attacks i had so far were script kids with public exploits
column17: and for them chroot does really the trick!'"

column10: b"b' LiraNuna could you please reopen this issue? This feature is needed as it is crucial to virtual hosting environments. Security aspect of chroot is perfectly valid in virtual environments
column11: especially with grsecurity extensions
column12: saying its not is completely insane.'"

column10: b"b' cc @paulbiss and @fredemmott '"
b"b' Why does this need to be part of HHVM? and upstart both support providing a chroot path
column11: and you can just run chroot directly too.'"

column10: b'b" Agree with @simonwelsh
column11: I\'m unclear on why this needs to be part of the hhvm binary."'

column10: b"b' I think chrooting via chroot or start-stop-daemon is more difficult as then you have to copy all needed files (lib
column11: dev
column12: ) in the to-be-chrooted subdirectory which can be a bit annoying and another security risk when you later forget to update the libraries in the chroot-subdir.  So a chroot by hhvm itself after start-up can be a convenient option. '"

column10: b'b" I\'m missing php-fpm chroot like feature
column11: where I could isolate php environments in virtual hosting in very efficient way each php thread could run as a different user
column12: have its own resource and security policy
column13: it works really well
column14: I could create small chrooted enviroments which were consistent with shell and php. If it could be achieved without integrating chroot feature into binary
column15: i\'d like to see such implementation with nginx."'

column10: b'b" @lutel I\'m a little confused
column11: you can\'t chroot a thread
column12: or run two threads from the same process as different users. @Thomas12 makes sense. I\'m still not totally sold on this feature
column13: but I\'d be willing to look at a PR if there\'s enough interest in adding it. We do have support for setuid so I suppose it\'s not without precedent."'

column10: b'b" @paulbiss in php-fpm each thread has it\'s own chrooted directory (eg. per one customer)
column11: an it is own by customer user. In php-fpm you can define separate pools
column12: and chroot each of them."'

column10: b"b' @lutel: php-fpm uses multiple processes
column11: not multiple threads. Multiple threads can not be chrooted differently. There can only be one chroot per process
column12: which dramatically limits the value of this for HHVM.'"

column10: b"b' @fredemmott indeed
column11: its per process. Why is this limitation for HHVM? In terms of resource usage these are almost the same...  13285  0.0  0.4 653604 80252 ?    S  06:17 0:01 php-fpm: pool hhvm   15013  0.0  0.5 608292 88728 ?    Ssl  Jan11 0:00 / -m server -c / -c / -u hhvm -vPidFile=/ -=/ -=/ -=fastcgi -=127.0.0.1 -=9000'"

column10: b"b' @lutel: hhvm is a jit
column11: and many of the performance benefits come from compiling machine code translations of php and caching them in a translation cache. As each request needs access to the translated machine code and associated data structures we run requests in threads rather than separate processes.'"

column10: b'b" @paulbiss yes
column11: but wouldn\'t be possible to create mechanism to chroot different hhvm processes (not threads)
column12: like we have in php-fpm? This feature of php-fpm that you can define multiple pools and chroot each of them is very convenient in virtual hosting. I\'d be interested to see if it is already possible to chroot hhvm like @simonwelsh mentioned."'

column10: b'b" The problem is that there aren\'t multiple processes handling requests within hhvm
column11: it\'s all done in a single multithreaded process. Short of substantially re-architecting both the server and the runtime I don\'t think a multiprocess solution is going to be possible. If you want to serve requests from different source trees in separate chroot jails you can always just spin up multiple servers and point them each at the source tree you want them to serve. This is something that should be done in a wrapper script
column12: not implemented in hhvm. It is possible to run hhvm in a chroot
column13: but as @Thomas12 mentioned you\'ll need to have the jail setup to contain all of the resources that hhvm will need to start
column14: libraries
column15: shells
column16: etc."'

column10: b'b" @paulbiss with php-fpm implementation
column11: jailing is also required
column12: but it is only what php requires in terms of  etc which is perfectly fine. Looking at both php-fpm and hhvm in terms of chroot
column13: i don\'t see they are that fart apart it is only that php-fpm supports in its config chrooting
column14: and does chrooting in according to whats configured in pools. Still the process would be isolated to one directory
column15: it doesn\'t seem like big architecture change...As you said
column16: it could be achieved with wrapper script
column17: i\'ll try to work on it."'

column10: b"b' @lutel: supporting a chroot jail would be quite doable
column11: in either a wrapper or within hhvm itself. Allowing hhvm to run requests in different processes and chroot them each individually would be a much larger undertaking
column12: that was my point.'"

b'b" I\'ve found that RuntimeOption::EvalProfileHWEnable option is used before options are parsed. b"b' HHVM over FastCGI hangs randomly with larger computations'"
b'b" I have written a small benchmarking suite that includes CLI tests for PHP
column11: HHVM and Zephir. I am now attempting to add FastCGI tests for PHP
column12: HHVM and Zephir. The [code is available]url  in the fcgi branch on GitHub. Essentially I have created a HHVM extension
column13: PHP and Hack version of the same Mandelbrot set generating code (see on GitHub project). For each of them I setup ( ) a HHVM FastCGI server
column14: warm it up by making a few requests against it and then benchmark with a number of runs (20 in these tests). The FastCGI request is handled by a C++ FastCGI CLI client (  git submodule). It works fine with Mandelbrot sets of 100x100 and 200x200
column15: but as soon as it is ramped up to 1
column17: 000 it randomly hangs during one of the 20 iterations for HHVM running PHP
column18: Hack or via the HHVM extension. Sometimes it makes it as far as iteration 17 or 18
column19: but normally it hangs after under 10 iterations. When I ask it to do a set of 2
column21: 000 it fails to complete one iteration. Unfortunately nothing is written to the HHVM logs either and it just silently hangs. If I kill the job and try to re-run it without stopping and starting the server it hangs without executing anything. So it is leaving the server in a failed state
column22: but not causing the server to crash or die. I have tried changing a number of config options see the related issue on my project: url  Incidentally the PHP scripts using PHP\'s and Zend OPcache take longer to run
column23: but they complete successfully every time (for sets 1000x1000
column24: 2000x2000 and 5000x5000) so I am pretty sure it isn\'t something in my client implementation
column25: but something in HHVM itself you never know though of course! The same test runs fine via HHVM on the CLI as well
column26: but not via FastCGI. So this could be caused by a configuration issue or by something in HHVM itself I have no idea
column27: but I would like to get it working so any help appreciated. I am just gonna ping @ptarjan here as from my previous ticket I believe this maybe your area of HHVM development. Additionally I am now running HHVM built from commit 190a12a7a5c8b79a16182107afad5ecc7971b303"'

b'b\' Thanks for the report! I can repro this
column11: and it looks like a legit bug. Here\\\'s an explanation of why this happens:works by literally deleting statements out of the named AST -anything until the end of the block.We flatten blocks during naming
column12: so the following two end up being the same:  This means that your gets clipped out by the  .We determine whether a function is a generator or not by the presence of any statement in the function body. But since the clipped out the
column13: we don\\\'t see it anymore.That means we don\\\'t think this is a generator -we don\\\'t see any return or yield at all
column14: and so we think it implicitly is  .If you stick an at the top level of the function (can be the last statement if you want)
column15: we\\\'ll skip our return type annotation check
column16: so this will be fine. But the check for "is there an  " only checks at top level
column17: in order to enforce as much as we can about the function. Figuring out what the right thing to do here is somewhat complicated and unclear -all of these decisions make sense in isolation
column18: they just don\\\'t work together :) IMO not requiring a keyword (like we do for
column19: which is why this doesn\\\'t happen there) was a serious error way back in the day. My suspicion of the right way to fix this is to make a new type of function
column20: next to and
column21: that we can compute on the full AST or on the NAST before clipping happens. But the whole mechanism for causes other issues
column22: so we may revisit that too. That said
column23: I\\\'m not sure this is hi-pri enough for us to get to any time soon. If you\\\'re going to take a crack at fixing it yourself
column25: and I can discuss and verify that the approach I say above is an acceptable one for us (before you spend a ton of work on it).\''

b"b' As far as I know
column11: Apache and nginx will just close the connection to the FastCGI server when the client aborts the request

column14: HHVM seems to crash due to this. HHVM crash output: HHVM command: Versions: Extract from strace: GDB: The recvfrom() line from strace contains both the FCGI_BEGIN_REQUEST and the FCGI_ABORT_REQUEST records (client aborts connection immediately). Could this also be the reason?'"

column10: b'b" What is the bug? You said you got the same error in PHP ~5.5. And if you look at PHP they have two implementations one that interact with mysqlnd and one that interact directly with the MySQL C API. Both are available and you can choose which one you want when you compile PHP. So if there are bugs because we don\'t use mysqlnd you should see the same in PHP if you compile it without using mysqlnd."'
b"b' neither bind_result or get_result are working in hhvm. i moved the balance function out of the class and into static functions and it works in php5
column11: but not in hhvm.'"

column10: b'b" I tested both of them when I implemented them. They worked for the tests I did. And we also passed a bunch of PHP\'s mysqli tests that used bind_result and bind_param. So if they don\'t work for you please file a bug that includes repro steps (that passes in PHP) so we can fix it. And both those functions works in PHP even if you compile PHP without mysqlnd so it shouldn\'t have anything to do with mysqlnd."'

b"b' Sorry I tested bind_result. get_result is not implemented because it is a lot harder to implement if not using mysqlnd. Which I guess is the reason it is only implemented in PHP if you use mysqlnd and not otherwise'"
b'b" yeah
column11: i know. i just didn\'t want to insult your work(but i still wish i could talk you into implementing mysqlnd). you guys are very good programmers
column12: for sure.i just think you are cutting an important corner by leaving out mysqlnd in my humble opinion. "'

column10: b'b" My guess is that if we used mysqlnd mysqli support would still not exists (it is that much more work). Mysqlnd contains over 20000 lines of code. That we would need to get to run inside HHVM. And if we used mysqlnd I wouldn\'t be surprised if things would be slower. And my reasoning for that is that mysqlnd internally uses the same structures as PHP so everything would need to get converted from PHP structures to HHVM structures. With that said. If someone want to implement mysqlnd I don\'t think anyone in the HHVM team would be against it. I just think it would take a lot of work. And the only thing you really get is get_result which I think you can actually implement completely in PHP in a day or two."'
b"b' alright thanks for taking the time to explain it to me. seems like it would be a waste of time
column11: although i will humbly request for get_result to be added to the current mysqli extension in hhvm. it really saves alot of code for me when i can use get result(which i need for certain queries where i have to select *). its an edge case i know
column12: but maybe if you get some free time in the next couple of months you could attend to it. once again
column13: i thank you for being so professional about it.'"

column10: b'b" I looked at this for a bit
column11: and it\'s annoying to fix :) The problem is that expanding typedefs only goes one level; we expand
column12: and then expand
column13: and since we see a when expanding we yell -the circularity check happens as part of expansion. But by that point we\'ve lost that we\'re expanding because it was part of
column14: and yell. Ideally we\'d do the circularity check once
column15: instead of every time we expand
column16: and then write a into the declaration heap if things fail. The problem is there\'s not a good time to do this -we could make it happen after naming but before declaration
column17: but those two happen together; there\'s no guarantee that naming of will happen before even declaration of  . I think the solution is to do what we do for the circularity check on classes
column18: which run into a lot of the same issues. Before declaring
column19: we\'d go and declare
column20: etc etc. We can do the circularity check as part of this
column21: just like we do with classes. Making sure that dependencies get tracked here is interesting
column22: not sure if it will just work out or not. In any event
column23: it\'s more work than I want to deal with right now. If anyone reading this is hitting this issue
column24: please comment here -if enough folks care
column25: then it _does_ become worth my time :)"'

column16: then feel free  to close it."'

column10: b"b' Regenerating parser with bison3 fails'"

b'b\' Bison 3.0 was released with Ubuntu 14.04 and is also included in other rolling distributions that people frequently use for development (e.g. Debian jessie). Regenerating the parser with " parser" fails in the following ways:Line spacing has changed
column11: so the seds fail. Changing the three sed calls to have "\\\\s+" instead of spaces fixes this (I have a patch for this at the Debian repository
column12: but no CLA yet
column13: so this description is probably okay...) (this is deprecated
column14: but seems to work so far
column15: so not as important)Finally
column16: the more important one that my lack of good bison & HHVM internals knowledge hasn\\\'t allowed me to fix. After regenerating the source
column17: the build output fails with: If you don\\\'t have bison3 handy
column18: I\\\'d be happy to provide the bison output here.\''

column10: b'b" This is broken: The commit above has this: but there\'s no line below it to readd the #endif after the YYTOKEN_ definitions
column11: which was presumably what the author intended
column12: so the guard\'s #if remains unclosed and breaks compilation."'

column10: b"b' @paravoid Running gave me this diff url  which compiled fine. Maybe you have a different version of bison 3? Can you send me a diff that makes the sed more robust?'"
b'b" @ptarjan I tracked it down. The #ifndef guard name is dependent on bison\'s output path. makehas this: So
column11: this is essentially the absolute path. So
column12: the guard becomes
column13: e.g.:  but makehas these seds: which do not match
column14: and are left there; at the same time
column15: makehas \\xe2\\x80\\xa6which means that the #endif is removed
column16: but the #ifndef is not
column17: hence cpp errors out. Looking at #line comments

column10: b"b' EDIT: I guess I had cause. Php does not natively reflectionclass methods __ get and __ set. Fixing this by commented __ method in ext_reflection_'"
b'b" The cause is that it\'s possible to implement the $name behavior with PHP\'s C API without implementing __get
column11: but our implementation of Reflection\\\\* is in PHP
column12: so we need __get"'

column10: b'b\' better fix of this problem is only remove "final" for __get + __set and all is working fine\''
b'b" That\'s not a good fix
column11: as we need them to maintain php5 compatibility in other ways (eg the name property)
column12: and there\'s no guarantee that subclasses will call them."'

column10: b'b" @fredemmott it\'s better if the programmer forgets to call than your final. There is a getter anyway and 99% of magic implementations do in fact just call
column11: which will also make it work. So calling of is not needed. Please do reconsider
column12: this is broken and needs to be fixed."'

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t think that\\\'s a fair characterization of the issue. Declaring the methods as here was designed to avoid a different incompatibility.I think @LiraNuna\\\'s point was that you could define a new class that wraps the if you really need this behavior. The wrapper would just call through to but would allow you to interpose your own and  .It\\\'s not really a glitch. There is no way to declare a property as "readonly" but PHP 5 lacks such an attribute in user space as well. I suppose we could allow this notion in PHP code within systemlib
column11: but it would be a lot of effort to implement with very little impact (this one place seems to be the only example of a use for it).If you feel strongly we\\\'re happy to hear suggestions / review PRs
column12: but at this time we aren\\\'t actively pursuing solutions.\''

b"b' I want to give you a status update. 3.1.22 will become a major release with a lot of improvements. So it takes some more time. Mit meanwhile I have done some testing with Smarty under HHVM. The hackificator tool was able to convert most of the Smarty code automatically. With some work we should get Smarty itself 100% compatible. The compiled template and cache PHP files are currently not compatible. But some brief tests have been successfull that we could generate these files directly as <?hh files if Smarty detects that it is running under HHVM.  My goal is to have HHVM support included in the 3.1.22 release. Current estimated time frame 2 3 weeks. I will keep you informed. Uwe'"
b'b" You don\'t need to _hackify_ the code (don\'t know what the tool does) nor use under HHVM. Unless you are converting the library to Hack."'

column10: b'b" I believe this is related to #2807.The BladeCompiler inside of Laravel is using token_get_all for its compileString function to tokenize and parse each token. If the compiled extension
column11: statement
column12: comment
column13: or echo falls in between the 400 character array
column14: it is split and continued in the next array and thus is not parsed.  Here\'s a simple example where will not be parsed and compiled... Becomes: Behind the scenes
column15: here\'s the var_dump of what gets passed to BladeCompiler parseToken function and so expressions are being spread over 2 sections of the token_get_all arrays resulting in the following:  becomes  in regular PHP land thats just a 666 character string however you can see from above it\'s being split into a 400 char array and a 266 char array. Any expressions caught in between 400 char arrays do not get compiled by blade.  Exists on stable  and  Laravel 4.2"'

column10: b'b" We have just been trying oauth (with Magento Enterprise 1.14) and we are getting an issue with: We are using wget to simulate the request. The following line of code throws the error from : I think the issue is potentially in Zend itself the documentation say\'s the last parameter should be a bool but Zend are passing an integer the question is this a hphp issue or an issue with the Zend code? The exception doesn\'t seem to get handled (nothing is output in our error logs or browser) The code works without issue with PHP 5.5 This is my hhvm error log reporting:  "'
b"b' @sgolemon what do you think? should we allow bool typehints to be ints?'"
b"b' This is basically due to #1669'"
b'b\' @ptarjan Looking at PHP5\\\'s zend_parse_arg_impl()
column11: for the the \\\'b\\\' arg type it will implicitly coerce null
column12: int
column13: double
column14: and string types to boolean without an error or a warning. Naturally
column15: for "bool" type hints in  user code we want to stick with the current behavior (no implicit coercion). For HNI
column16: I think it makes sense to offer an option that mimics PHP5\\\'s extension parameter logic (i.e. zend_parse_parameters()). It looks like HNI already has a "__ParamCoerceModeFalse" attribute to adjust how parameters are handled. Does this do the trick or could it be updated to work? If not
column17: maybe add new attribute(s) for this purpose?\''

column10: b'b" @paroski: I have code that propagates it to the jit and makes it work in the interpreter. I\'ve not done the neccessary code-gen for the jit yet. This should be somewhat easier once @sgolemon\'s changes for CoerceStk land."'
b'b" So yeah
column11: Zend is bad for passing an int
column12: and they should feel bad. That said
column13: there\'s a reason all HNI methods have ParamCoerceMode enabled by default.  hash_hmac() is implemented in PHP
column14: so it doesn\'t get the benefit of coerce mode.  I wouldn\'t be against taking the typehints off entirely
column15: tbqh."'

column10: b"b' @ryne-andal we came with a workaround though. If you are using nginx then catch the 500 error response from the upstream and proxy your request internally to another script which clears the corrupted session for you and then redirect the user silently. I know that is a dirty hack but it has been a lifesaver for us during last holiday season and we are still relying on it. The only drawback to that solution is that the customer gets kicked out and has to re-login. '"

column10: b'b\' You may also want to list this as a difference between PHP and Hack.As stated in the section "String access and modification by character " in the current [PHP manual]url **_NOTE:**_ Strings may also be accessed using braces
column11: as in $str{42}
column12: for the same purpose. While the current HHVM implementation does work as defined by the PHP manual
column13: the hh_client rejects this as an error. It sounds as if you are saying that hh_client is correct
column14: in which case HHVM should also report an error. Either that or hh_client should accept the use of braces. While I understand this is a low priority issue
column15: it would be best that HHVM and hh_client agree.\''

column10: b'b" HHVM is the authority on PHP (or
column11: rather
column12: upstream
column13: which HHVM endeavors to emulate)
column14: but is the authority on what is valid Hack. Executing code which the typechecker doesn\'t accept is undefined behavior. (This is a little weird
column15: but exists for technical and historical reasons which I can go into if you\'re really curious.)"'

column10: b"b' Assertion failure: deltaFits(table
column11: sz::dword) on OSX'"

column10: b"b' Installed 3.3.0 using Homebrew. On execution of any script I get this issue: Assertion failure: deltaFits(table
column11: sz::dword)Destructor function table is expected to be in the data segment
column12: with addresses less than 2^31 /-gen-helpers-x64.h:215: HPHP::jit::MemoryRef HPHP::jit::X64::lookupDestructor(HPHP::jit::X64Assembler&
column13: HPHP::jit::PhysReg): assertion '"

column10: b"b' Have you tried to delete your  ?'"
b'b" I don\'t have one presumably the process has never got that far."'
b"b' Seems to be the same problem as #3427. You can try downgrading to HHVM 3.1.0.'"
b'b" Yes
column11: it\'s the same as #3427. Both are examples of trying to emit a call from JIT code to C++ and the JIT expects the C++ target to be within 2^31 bytes. Something about the OSX code layout is different and apparently is breaking the assumption."'

column10: b'b" A workaround for this (on linux
column11: or osx) would be to turn off whatever is causing unhappy binary layout. A real fix needs to modify the jit to dynamically generate different code if the dtor table isn\'t close to the JIT code segment."'

column10: b"b' This might have caused the problem for destructors
column11: but probably not for array vtables (#3427)url '"

column10: b"b' Is there any additional debug I could provide that would help shed light on the issue?'"
b"b' I run into this issue on my Hardened Gentoo server with the grsecurity / PaX patches.  3.15.8 Kernel config: url This is probably due to the ASLR options enabled.'"
b'b" @ptarjan giving this to you because I have no idea what i\'m doing with github :-). it would be good if we can get this fixed for the 3.3 release. I know how to do it
column11: but I might not have a lotta time in the next couple days."'

column10: b"b' sketch of a fix: modify the address-prep logic for CppCall::ArrayVirt and ::Destructor
column11: so they handle the situation when the call table is not nearby (ie deltaFits(...)==false). This will require a scratch register to load the table address
column12: but that should be fine if we do it just before the call; rax should be free
column13: as well as other non-arg
column14: caller-save registers.'"

column10: b'b" Or
column11: a better way: check once
column12: before the JIT starts (like
column13: when we\'re generating unique stubs)
column14: if those tables are nearby. if not
column15: copy them to the JIT data segment
column16: and save the pointer. then we always can use them with RIP-relative addressing."'

column10: b'b" It\'s just dawned on me. I\'m fairly sure that this is an issue with HHVM not reading the config file without explicitly specifying it. The error was occurring in PHP scripts that call the HHVM executable again. Symfony does this to run the commands after the composer installations or updates. When it does it though
column11: it doesn\'t call HHVM with the config parameter set. This must be the issue that was fixed in 3.4.0-dev. It\'s actually not difficult to work around either!"'

column10: b"b' Having the same issue. Cannot use HHVM 3.3.0 with Symfony from console app.'"
b"b' I have the exact same problem too.any update?'"
b"b' Hi guys
column11: Essentially
column12: the problem here does lie with HHVM. For some reason HHVM 3.3.0 requires that you explicitly state which configuration files to use (e.g.  ). This will fix a lot of PHP commands if you have the required config value in to enable loading XML over other streams again (i.e. file
column13: http). This solution alone however is not enough with Symfony. For instance
column14: when you run composer install / update and the postscripts are run
column15: it calls php (or HHVM in this case) internally this time without the explicit configuration file setting being set.  This happens somewhere in a file called . For the project I was using this on
column16: I simply extended that class
column17: and added some additional logic to always call HHVM with the config variable set. Then placed that in my  so it would run in stead of the default one. I hope this points some of you in the right direction at least. (The alternative is to just use HHVM 3.4.0 the nightly build
column18: this may not be possible for some people though!).'"

column16: slotting in the HHVM executable check. The

column11: but there is no resolution for it yet. You need to have a non-strict file which invokes  .'"

column10: b"b' which means I can not have a hack file that executes a piece of code by itself?'"
b'b" Exactly. This is one of the few reason Facebook doesn\'t have **everything** in hack. You need a main entry point."'
b"b' oh. thanks!'"
b'b\' The "workaround" for this is to have one non-strict Hack file that is the call to and then that file in your strict file. Allowing one function call in strict seems reasonable
column11: but may not be as easy as you might think from a type checking perspective. cc: @jwatzman are we still investigating a way to do this?\''

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: what has been said here is correct -it\'s impossible to have a 100% strict project since you need at least this one toplevel line in partial mode. We\'ve plans to fix it but haven\'t gotten around to it yet. We all agree that having a system where you can\'t write 100% of your code in the preferred mode is kind of silly :)"'

column10: b'b\' +1 this is annoying and "silly". I write a lot of single-file programs and I\\\'d like to use // strict.\''
b'b" As for why: it\'s not generally possible to make top-level code \'safe\' due to things like how locals are sort-of global
column11: and strict mode does not allow any unsafe code. If we just allowed it
column12: the typechecker would be allowing code it doesn\'t fully understand
column13: which would go against the usual expectation of strict mode. Whatever\'s done to address this needs to be more involved than simply removing the restriction."'

column10: b"b' I _think_ @int3 is going to allow a single function call at toplevel
column11: which should be safe. (We talked about it last week at least.) That would solve a large part of the problem here without being unsafe.'"

column10: b'b\' How\\\'s about this. Main can be a well defined class or function. If there is a class that matches the signature
column11: call it. In some sense
column12: that\\\'s what every language does. Java has a lot of problems with this exact launching problem
column13: because they\\\'re not willing to have a "sensible default policy" but that doesn\\\'t hurt anything about type checking.\''

column10: b'b" I\'d rather just allow calling functions with no arguments at toplevel -it\'s a lot more familiar to existing PHP devs
column11: it doesn\'t require changes to the runtime
column12: and I also always found the magic of Java too
column13: well
column14: magical and confusing."'

column11: which is not a reference. So you can try: Both hhvm 3.3 and 3.4 work. Part 2 If I only correct $data but not $fields

column14: all other php files will have corruption and return various errors. When using
column15: hhvm crashes in serialize(). However
column16: hhvm shouldn\\\'t crash. Adding some checks about if the variable has the correct type in  to stop executing the function from reflection or in ext_ (line 129) can prevent from toInt64Helper() crashing and corruption. Part 3 If I change the lines to to remove the reflection and use the normal way to call bind_param()
column17: hhvm 3.4 will not show any results. hhvm 3.3 is fine. I did a bisecting and found that url  caused the problem. I didn\\\'t see any leak with extraArgs without this commit. My understanding is that bind_param_helper() in ext_ stores all the arguments in a vector and calls arReturn() at the end. The reference variables are freed in arReturn() due to this commit
column18: so update_result() in mysql_ can\\\'t set the result later ( ). Part 4: Memory leak Since that commit was about fixing memory leak
column19: I reverted that commit and did a stress test. I found that the memory leaked so fast that somewhere else must be leaking. jemalloc profiling dumps showed MySQLStmt::bind_result() leaked. It turned out that ~MySQLStmt() and ~MySQLStmtVariables() were never called. The buffer will also leak if the result has strings. Every time hhvm runs your scripts above
column20: it will be gradually leaking memory (about 1 requests in my testing).\''

b"b' HHVM and hh_server disagree about argument variance'"
b"b' Hack Type checker reports error if we set the argument type of unserialize to mix. It says it should be a string
column11: however HHVM works the other way.POC: url  url '"

column10: b'b" Yeah this is a rather unfortunate longstanding inconsistency between how HHVM and hh_client see the type system. As far as hh_client is concerned
column11: functions can be overridden and change  types via the usual rules of . In HHVM
column12: it follows PHP\'s rules for argument types -if the type is in an interface method or abstract method
column13: then it must be textually the same in any implementations. (Otherwise you can do whatever.) We need to resolve this
column14: by relaxing HHVM\'s enforcement of this PHP rule in Hack code
column15: but it turns out to be tricky. The recent PHP RFC for return types originally specified covariance but went back on that after they ran into similar implementation difficulties :) So we\'ll fix eventually
column16: but for now
column17: you\'ll have to drop the type
column18: or change it to something such as that HHVM itself doesn\'t enforce. Sorry :("'

column10: b'b" (And I thought there was already an issue on github about this
column11: but I can\'t find it
column12: so keeping this one open.)"'

column10: b"b' @dabek ran into this internally this week'"
b"b' Current behavior: when using autoloading via
column11: the failure function will be called if the function cannot be found in the current namespace. _Then_ we will try to find the function in the global namespace. Exepected behavior: we should look for the function in the global namespace before calling the failure function
column12: and only call the failure function if it exists in neither place (current or global namespace).'"

column12: toy examples notwithstanding."'

column10: b"b' This appears to have been fixed already.'"
b"b' segfault when overwriting internal constructors'"

b'b" This is a problem with more or less all internal objects.They never check if the ctor was actually successfully executed.   The individual segfaults can be fixed individually (and the same fixed applied to all the other methods too)
column11: or is there a plan to mark internal objects like this automatically to require the ctor to be called or is the intentions to be 100% compatible with PHP here and deal with it in individual methods? I started writing a patch for the individual methods
column12: but now I\'m curious if a better solution is in the works."'

column10: b"b' We do some critical processing in the constructor. A temporary fix would be to call from the instance constructor
column11: but the best fix would be to move some of the initialization in to a new builtin  . The builtin is a special instance initializer available to builtins that is always run regardless of whether or not a subclass has its own constructor.'"

column10: b"b' Interesting. I imagine then all logic from builtin __construct()ors should more or less always be done in __init__.Should I go over a few of the builtin classes and shuffle these things?'"
b'b" Sure
column11: I would be careful of constructors that take arguments though. I don\'t think there\'s any mechanism to forward these to since it\'s called first. Those may require both."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t think thats the right fix though now that I look at it.Even though __init__ issues a warning
column11: the execution continues as-if nothing happend but it shouldn\'t
column12: chances are it simply can\'t (and therefore leading to the segfault). In PHP a warning is issued and NULL returned.This is done per method
column13: usually using a ...CHECK_INITIALIZED() macro"'

column10: b"b' Right
column11: there are two separate problems here. (1) Some natives require special initialization that has to happen even if they get subclassed
column12: that problem is solved by defining an which always gets called regardless of whether the subclass has its own constructor
column13: and (2) a constructor getting called with invalid arguments. The solution for (2) is trickier but I like your idea of throwing an exception.'"

column10: b'b" Since PHP doesn\'t call parent constructors in case of overrides
column11: I think it\'s natural to _always_ call a parent constructor manually. The same case is with any user-level class: if you don\'t call the parent constructor (that potentially and very likely does an important base initialization)
column12: you can\'t expect correct work of an inherited instance. PHP issues a warning on calling the
column13: i.e. it has a check in every method: Using doesn\'t seem solve the issue
column14: since can\'t propagate params. Though that\'s said
column15: in PHP semantics
column16: a derived class should always call the parent constructor. To conform PHP
column17: seems we should not allocate a doc in (and it\'s not possible without correct params)
column18: but to have checks in methods
column19: that the doc was created."'

column10: b'b\' I think it might make sense to use to put the document into some defined "default" state and then let the constructor modify the state based on the passed parameters since it\\\'s called after init anyway. That way even if the constructor is never called any internal structures will have been initialized. What we want to avoid is a segmentation fault
column11: having the dom document be unusable without calling the constructor is acceptable as long as it doesn\\\'t crash the process.\''

column10: b'b\' Keep in mind this is applicable to likely all other builtin classes.A generic way of marking an class "must call the ctor
column11: or else fail all other method calls" would be best solution as it is an easy mistake to make for extension authors too.\''

column10: b'b" OK
column11: yeah
column12: we should use then to avoid segfaults. However
column13: all methods will have to have guards on depending props (like doc) to be initialized.We could potentially add a warning specifically for base extension classes (in case if they are extended
column14: and the derived class doesn\'t call  ). However
column15: in generic case don\'t think it\'s possible
column16: since PHP allows overriding constructors without calling the parent one
column17: and assumes that the parent will be called manually. So still the main fix with correct semantics would be calling even if we\'ll fix the uninit data with  ."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not sure what the best approach is here. There are classes in PHP 5 where it\'s safe to not call the parent constructor
column11: we should maintain compatibility in these cases. I have not checked the behavior of DOMDocument. We don\'t necessarily need guards in all of the dependent properties
column12: if they\'re initialized to a default that\'s safe to access in it doesn\'t matter that they were never set int he constructor because it wasn\'t called. Anyway
column13: the approach here should be to look at classes that have this sort of initialization issue and see how they behave in PHP 5 before deciding on what sort of error or default initialization state they should have when the builtin constructor isn\'t called."'

column11: that still segfaults:  '"

column10: b"b' Ping is anything going to happen with this?'"
b"b' Can we just implement a special case in the VM that
column11: for built-in classes implemented in C++
column12: the superclass constructor is _always_ called first (and any explicit calls to it in the user constructor are ignored)?  That would make the job much easier
column13: without requiring a (slow!) run-time check on every method call.'"

column10: b"b' The Extension API check does not work.'"
b'b" The Extension class constructor implementation is provided in the cppfile. So when the extension\'s static object s_##name_extension is constructed
column11: the constructor called is in the HHVM binary and hence the m_hhvmAPIVersionprivate member variable is initialized to HHVM_API_VERSION defined in thebinary itself
column12: not what it was when the extension was compiled.The patch moves the Extension constructor to the header file to fix the issue."'

b"b' Cache time zone validity and add lock for calling timelib on Mac.'"

b"b' date_default_timezone_set() is called once for every WordPress request instock WordPress 4.1.1. Cache the time zone validity for better performance. A lock is needed when calling timelib_timezone_id_is_valid() becausesetlocale() on Mac is not thread safe. When the first argument to setlocaleis LC_CTYPE
column11: loadlocale() will call __setrunelocale() to modify the globallocale object and double free can happen and crash. url  Part of #4444.'"

column12: and nearly all of them were placed based solely on intuition."'

b"b' url url How we want to deal with the BC here is interesting
column11: alongside PHP5 and Hack.'"

column10: b'b\' Plan is to have the parser support both (somehow
column11: hopefully through some not-totally-ugly Bison or preprocessor magic; an "ambiguous parser" AST node would be really nice so we can do this in a pass later
column12: without forking the parser). There will be an INI option to set whether you want the PHP5 or PHP7 behavior
column13: and another INI option to override that to the other setting for a list of directories. This is the best way we came up with to allow mixed projects without breaking compat with PHP5/PHP7 themselves (different opening tags) or without doing something ugly like file extensions or semantically-meaningful comments.\''

column10: b"b' That sounds like pretty big overkill. To the best of my knowledge the BC impact of this change is very low in practice and it should not break the world to just switch this at some point.'"
b'b" It\'s still a BC break
column11: and a very subtle one at that. And we\'ll need the switch for more than just this one I think
column12: for a couple other BC breaks in PHP7 like typehints or array->string conversion."'

column10: b'b" I\'m starting to look into what the parser changes might have to look like to support both."'
b'b" Relevant commits seem to beurl url url  @nikic does that seem reasonable? (Plus a few refactors you did that we may or may not want to do
column11: depending on whether it makes it easier or harder to maintain the PHP5/PHP7 split.) Our parser originally traces its lineage back to PHP\'s
column12: enough so that it\'s pretty straightforward to make equivalent changes to ours... the actual parser changes don\'t seem that painful if we could just make them. But figuring out how to generate two bison outputs from one input is what I\'m currently thinking through. doesn\'t really work since there are other preprocessor directives in there we don\'t want expanded until the file is actually compiled (_after_ it\'s run through bison). I\'d really love to just pull out the 5-10 different rules though. Maybe some shell script / sed magic
column13: though that\'s pretty ugly and painful to read / regenerate. There\'s also probably some lexer hack we could do (e.g.
column14: is T_PHP5_DOLLAR or T_PHP7_DOLLAR
column15: so certain rules only work sometimes depending on what the lexer spits out
column16: and there\'s a bison rule that is either one if you don\'t care). But that\'s not necessarily generalizable
column17: and probably even _harder_ to  :)"'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m going to try the "split out part of the bison file and use sed to inject the right version"
column11: which I _think_ will work well for the three commits above. I need to remember this RFC also added new syntax (or
column12: rather
column13: made syntax that you would have thought would have work all along
column14: actually work)
column15: which could put a wrench in that
column16: will need to investigate.\''

b"b' Any plans for LLVM back-end for Hack?'"
b"b' Hi! This is more of a question: Does the team have any plans on implementing an LLVM back-end for Hack
column11: to compile  to binary code?'"

column10: b"b' Already info here: url  **Edit**: OK
column11: not so much info. :) Any progress?'"

column10: b'b" HHVM is going to remain a JIT -we\'re not going to produce standalone binaries for PHP or Hack. (The ancient HPHPc did that
column11: and it turns out a JIT can optimize better.) There are continuing experiments in using LLVM as part of the JITting process -basically
column12: after we go through our bytecode and IR
column13: instead of emitting x64 assembly
column14: we emit LLVM bitcode
column15: which LLVM can then optimize and generate x64. LLVM is pretty slow
column16: so we\'d only do this for the hottest of hot code. The experiments are ongoing
column17: @edwinsmith can comment if he wants; last I heard
column18: they had gotten the LLVM pipeline to performance parity with the existing one
column19: and were working on making it actually generate _faster_ code :) But again
column20: this is all internal performance work; there won\'t be any user-visible implications of this other than faster code."'

column10: b'b" Thanks for your answer! It\'s interesting that a JIT gives better performance result than a conventional compiler I better google some more about that. :) Have a good one!"'
b'b" The benefit is all in type information -since you\'re compiling the code just-in-time
column11: you know what the types of everything are
column12: since you have everything right there. Being able to type-specialize the code so well turns out to be a big deal -you can do this easily with a statically typed language like C
column13: but for PHP (or Python or Ruby etc etc)
column14: having a JIT is a huge win due to this."'

column10: b'b" It is technically possible for an AOT compile  process
column11: used in the context of repo-authoritative
column12: and not generating PIC code
column13: and generating for a specific arch
column14: such as the known configuration of a production server
column15: to produce faster code
column16: primarily because time becomes far less of a factor in what optimizations can be done. HHBBC does this to some extent I believe
column17: but it operates at the bytecode level
column18: and doesn\'t AOT compile code."'

column10: b"b' IIRC HHVM actually does
column11: up to a point
column12: generate PIC code currently
column13: but I believe that is only for the purpose of re-ordering hot functions close together in memory. '"

column10: b'b" @Orvid we actually emit highly optimized translations for hot code paths based on PGO data collected using profiling translations. These take longer to compile and use type information and branch profiling collected at runtime. In theory an AOT compiler could do the same PGO but it would require multiple deployments and would be unable to adapt to changing execution paths without a further profile-restart cycle. HHBBC does do some of this analysis ahead of time for any time information that can be inferred before collecting profile data. HPHPc (the previous incarnation of this project) transpiled PHP to C++ and used gcc to generate highly optimized binaries. We found it to be quite efficient
column11: but have discovered that the ceiling on performance for a language as dynamic as PHP is much higher with a JIT than an AOT compiler. Additionally
column12: we\'ve been able to support an array of language features that were basically impossible under an AOT model bringing HHVM much closer to PHP 5 than HPHPc ever got."'

column10: b'b" How stable is HHBBC? What are the requirements for the code to actually run it on? How much of a difference does it make in performance? There isn\'t any documentation on it on the Wiki."'
b'b" It runs facebook and has worked with most of the open source code I\'ve tested it with
column11: so I think it\'s pretty stable. As it\'s repo-mode it only supports a subset of PHP
column12: in particular it doesn\'t support eval
column13: and a handful of the more dynamic PHP features. As for performance it depends on a lot on the code-base
column14: the power of HHBBC is going to depend a lot on how much it can infer from context
column15: which in turn is going to depend on how cleanly and clearly the code is written. We should document it better."'

column10: b'b" We should
column11: but OTOH
column12: most people don\'t need to know about it
column13: since it automatically runs when building a repo. If you\'re using repo-auth
column14: you almost certainly built your repo with HHBBC unless you did something very weird and undocumented."'

column10: b'b" In Hack strict mode
column11: don\'t you have all the type information needed to make it as fast as
column12: say
column13: Java? In theory."'

column10: b'b" Java doesn\'t have complete type information
column11: because you can load more things at runtime. In some ways
column12: you do have more type information in hack strict mode
column13: assuming you\'re also in rope-authoritative mode
column14: as you know every piece of code that it\'s possible to execute. That assumes however that the core PHP functions are strictly declared
column15: and
column16: for the most part
column17: they aren\'t. "'

column10: b'b\' You also don\\\'t necessarily have info about any partial mode functions you call
column11: and there\\\'s always UNSAFE. The entire type system of Hack is built up such that if information is missing we go "I guess you know what you\\\'re doing" and admit it. In HHVM
column12: you can\\\'t do this
column13: since if you\\\'re wrong you\\\'ll segfault
column14: which is why HHBBC has its own much more conservative inference engine (which uses the Hack type annotations when it can).\''

column10: b'b" Persistent sockets aren\'t very persistent"'
b'b" Persistent sockets will work when reused in the same page request. However after a page request completes
column11: it appears the persisted socket is closed
column12: and thus a new page request on the same thread will be unable to use the persisted socket and a new connection will be created. It appears this is sweep\'s fault. I think File and Socket\'s implementation of sweep is doing too much. They\'ll call closeImpl on the data object which will close the
column13: but that will also happen in the data object\'s destructor
column14: so I think we can remove that extra call to closeImpl and just rely on that happening when the data object\'s refcount hits zero."'

b"b' Still missing as of 3.12.1.'"
b'b" I would submit a pull request
column11: but I want to clarify the underlying implementation.  For socket streams it _might_ make sense to change SO_RCVLOWAT if that is .  Also
column12: the PHP documentation url  isn\'t clear
column13: so I have to assume $buffer_size is bytes."'

column10: b'b" In PHP that sets the size of the internal buffer used to read or write
column11: though I\'m not sure its interaction with Sockets. is in bytes though."'

column10: b'b" Are you thinking just wrap stream_set_read_buffer() and stream_set_write_buffer() which adjusts the socket or file buffer?  Or did you have another buffer in mind?  For Linux sockets we could also set SO_RCVLOWAT which sets the minimum number of input bytes to receive before processing unfortunately the send version isn\'t implemented in Linux... If we don\'t like any of these
column11: it might be better to just leave unimplemented."'

column10: b'b\' I believe in PHP it\\\'s more high level
column11: since it applies to streams only (which are wrapper for native sockets). However the ZE implementation is well
column12: rather poor in my opinion. I have one test in my project which actually verifies proper chunking and I often see it randomly fails **without any code changes**. So tbh in PHP doesn\\\'t mean "give me data in chunks of X bytes" but "I suggest you to use chunks around X bytes" which is ridiculous.\''

column10: b'b" There\'s both a buffer and a chunk size."'
b'b" Streams can also be used with File operations
column11: but I\'m only aware of chunk size as a Network concept.  Based on @kiler129 experience (which will return less data than requested in some situations) it sounds like it is depending DIRECTLY on the underlying sockets library to handle chunk size
column12: which isn\'t the most fully features (at least under Linux) as it can only be used to control receive side.  Anyway
column13: I\'ll submit a pull request in a little while and let further discussion take place there."'

column11: but implementing it fully is still planned."'

column10: b'b" Tested with hhvm-nightly-dbg_2015.12.17~wheezy_amd64.deb today to confirm this issue is still happening.  It is.  Here is a core dump from those tests: Previously I\'d mentioned that this happens even when HHVM isn\'t handling any requests.  Turns out that wasn\'t really true. Nagios uses check_http to make requests
