column10: b"b' HHBC in non-authoritative mode allows code injection by vulnerable code'"
b'b" In non-RepoAuthoritative mode
column11: the following scenario is conceivable (AIUI):The administrator has an app under // and files underneath it are owned by and have mode (  for directories)HHVM runs with  HHVM is configured with in non-authoritative modeThe administrator has a / file with a text field that is being  ed on submission (arbitrary code execution) and has forgotten to place it behind authentication (feel free to replace this  example with any kind of vulnerable PHP code here) An attacker that gets access to  thus can run code as user hhvm. That is obviously bad\\xe2\\x84\\xa2 anyway
column12: but is made even worse by HHVM
column13: since the attacker can now inject bytecode into HHBC and thus override the execution of any other code path (including e.g. /). Ways these could be better:HHVM could open the fd to HHBC before dropping privileges
column14: thus leaving HHBC owned by and not injectable by PHP code running by itself.HHVM could allow HHBC to remain in-memory in the default configuration
column15: using SQLite3\'s [in-memory databases]url  Setting to manually works now but is not shared across different  s
column16: which I _think_ HHVM is using. Allowing SQLite3 URIs in that config option and setting the default to could potentially mitigate this."'

column10: b'b" There is definitely a potential issue there but since it requires already exposing an eval() hole I\'m going to close it."'

b'b\' I respectfully disagree with  this bug. This is a bit similar to having a writeable executable memory space \\xe2\\x80\\x94 something that the security community has gone considerable lengths to protect from in OSes and CPU architectures (W^X
column11: NX etc.). Using the same example
column12: saying that "this requires exposing an eval() hole" is the equivalent of saying that "this requires code that writes to executable memory" to dispute the need for W^X. eval() is just one of the ways this can be exploited anyway \\xe2\\x80\\x94 being able to write to  by e.g. a buggy upload form would be equivalently easy to implement.  This is a real issue that can be used from multiple attack vectors. There are a few easy ways to fix it
column13: I think
column14: as I\\\'ve proposed above. Please do reconsider the status and priority of this bug.\''

column11: but I think the PHP behavior might actually be a bug: url  url "In general
column12: it is allowed to seek past the end-of-file; if data is then written
column13: reads in any unwritten region between the end-of-file and the sought position will yield bytes with value 0. However

column16: let me know if the goal is to try and replicate PHP\\\'s current behavior...  Some of the existing  are in conflict with that behavior.\''

column10: b'b\' Thanks for the feedback @Orvid
column11: Yes this PC had 512MB and hhvm works great with everything else I throw at it. However there is an issue with it trying to cache everything to RAM with the readfile & fpassthru functions . This isn\\\'t how url  says the functions are supposed to work. With output buffering disabled they should stream the data out from the 1st kb.I have even tried the below code
column12: but the same result. As you can see I\\\'m flushing the output every kb ### Poor Man\\\'s fpassthru while (1) {  $buff=fread($output
column13: 1024);  if ($buff==FALSE || $buff=="")    break;  echo $buff;  @ob_end_flush();} This looks like a defect in hhvm that tries to cache the entire response to memory before sending it over to nginx thro fastcgi even though output buffering is turned off completely.  I even edited / and set output_buffering=OffIf I run top I can see hhvm increasing its memory usage until it runs out of RAM and crashes. RAM isn\\\'t the issue as hhvm should be able to support even 4+ GB files if the streaming works right.\''

b"b' Different floating point results with on modern machines (-ffp-contract)'"
b'b\' We\\\'ve observed
column11: that on modern machines (arm64 machines or Intel Haswell+) the selftest  fails
column12: because of a calculated value which does not match the expected value (we got 9.6226631046689 instead of 9.622663104669).  The reproduce the issue gcc needs to emit FMA (floating-point multiply-add) instructions
column13: which will be done by default when using -O2 when the target system supports them (arm64 or Intel Haswell+).  So a function like this:   results in this code on arm64:   and this code on x64 Haswell (-march=native):   The FMA instruction does not round the intermediate result (of the multiplication). This can lead to the result to be more precise (which is different than expected).  GCC offers the flag -ffp-contract to disable emitting contracted floating-point instructions (-ffp-contract=off). I can prepare a patch for putting that flag to the CFLAGS
column14: but I don\\\'t know if this is the desired "fix" for the issue.  An alternative solution would be to compare imprecise (value must be within epsilon environment of expected value).  Our analysis showed that the affected code by this issue is in timelib
column15: where astro.c contains lots of lines like  . Note
column16: that this means that PHP (5/7) is affected by this issue as well.  What is the desired fix for this issue?\''

column10: b"b' Mentioning @mxw @ptomsich @swalk-cavium @dave-estes '"
b"b' Hmm
column11: I wonder here.  PowerPC has the same issue too.  The difference between the two numbers is 1^-12% not enough to even worry about.  Though there are other cases where the difference matters a lot.  I think the biggest question here is what are the requirements for floating point with PHP
column12: is 1-2 ulp difference ok not to worry about it?  '"

column10: b'b\' @apinski-cavium PHP (the language) is not affected as the JIT does (currently) not emit such instructions. It is just about C/C++ code which gets compiled by GCC (e.g. timelib). Interesting fact is
column11: that the result is "equal or more correct" than before (I guess that\\\'s why it is turned on by default in GCC).\''

I guess we need to hear from the PHP language lawyers.  I did find a couple of packages which suggest somewhere someone is doing numerical analysis in php.  url  '"

b"b' @mxw how to deal with the same problem in libgd?  Test case  fails
column11: when arrAffine contains floats. The reason is that the function gdAffineApplyToPointF() in gd_ contains C++ code
column12: which g++ converts to FMA instructions:   arm64 GCC on Ubuntu Xenial:   We could append to the  . However
column13: it is not possible to set this for the gd extension only
column14: so the flag would be set for the whole HHVM project. '"

column10: b"b' Christoph
column11: Let\\xe2\\x80\\x99s keep the use of FMADD on AArch64
column12: as it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s not a ISA extension but an ISA feature.I would consider this an issue in the test-case again (if a test-case fails). For what it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s worth
column13: FP contraction should always be preferable to compounded rounding errors from individual FP instructions.Usually the code using individual instructions will have a slightly less accurate result. Phil.'"

column10: b'b\' Hey sorry for the newbie question but what do you mean by "And delete your existing repo."?  Thank you\''
b"b' The existing repo is the file that was having permission problems: This is roughly the equivalent to the opcache that is used in zend.  The repo that is created by default
column11: serves as a cache so we do not need to keep parsing the php files.  For more advanced use (and more performance)
column12: you can additionally enable repo authoritative mode. In that case you precompile your php into a repo and run a global optimization pass on the repo.'"

b"b' Unexpected breakage in 3.18.0 involving classname and instanceof'"
b'b" ### HHVM Version  3.18.0  ### Standalone code
column11: or other way to reproduce the problem  We\'ve been relying on similar code in our persistence layer
column12: but after moving from 3.12.0 to 3.18.0 we\'ve started receiving type checking errors which seem nonsensical to me. 3v4 seems to indicate that this worked up until and including 3.17.1
column13: so the change in behavior is probably in 3.18.0. I don\'t see how type erasure can affect this
column14: as neither nor are of a generic type. It\'s possible that I\'m missing some subtle loophole that would allow unsafe behavior
column15: but it seems safe to me. The change has been highly inconvenient
column16: as we\'ve had to resort to very fugly workarounds to deal with this.  <?hh // strict  interface A   {   }  function cast(classname $cn
column17: mixed $val): ?T   {   return $val instanceof $cn ? $val : null;   }  ### Expected result  No errors!  ### Actual result  :9:12
column18: 30: \'instanceof\' cannot be used on a generic classname because types are erased at runtime (Typing[4162]) "'

column10: b'b" This has been reported in url  The message is misleading
column11: but the problem is real: on a isn\'t sound
column12: because can be instantiated with a type (e.g.  ) some of which gets erased (to  ) at runtime."'

column10: b'b" I reported this very unsoundness problem with and type erasure in #6407. And it *still* breaks
column11: despite the fact that in that case it\'s known at compile time that the type to the right of is generic. And yet this particular case (which is used safely in practice) no longer type checks. What gives?"'

column10: b'b" Can anyone perhaps clarify the status of this issue? It\'s been closed
column11: then reopen
column12: then marked duplicate but kept open.  I can\'t come up with an explanation as to why a straightforward
column13: guaranteed-broken case described in #6407 remains broken
column14: but the behavior described in this issue is now caught by the type checker. I think that for consistency\'s sake either both need to be fixed
column15: or should remain unchecked for this particular cause of potential unsoundness altogether."'

column10: b'b\' Commit url  puts the rejection of classname under the same experimental flag as the "safe instanceof" feature that supports instanceof on generic classes in a safe way. If the flag isn\\\'t set
column11: the old behaviour is maintained.\''

column10: b"b' That sounds reasonable. Would it make sense to close this issue then? As well as #6407
column11: for that matter?'"

column10: b'b" I\'m going to close this one.  The other issues might be worth keeping open and pointing people towards url "'
b"b' Hack calls methods members'"
b"b' ### HHVM Version ### Standalone code
column11: or other way to reproduce the problem ### Expected result An error about the method in having the wrong number of arguments ### Actual result Hack calls a member instead. '"

column10: b'b\' Is this wrong? It correctly says "Too few arguments". And using the term member function isn\\\'t that much off either.\''
b"b' Is the issue with the wording of vs  ? I think this is the intended wording.'"
b'b" Yes
column11: the problem is with the word  . Member tends to refer to [properties]url  not methods. PHP also calls functions inside a class methods
column12: so there shouldn\'t be a reason for Hack to diverge in terminology."'

column10: b'b\' I think this is intentional.  The term "member function" is a synonym for "method".  The word "member" could refer to either member functions
column11: or member variables.  In this case it was referring to a member function.\''

column10: b'b" If you submit a PR I would try to get it by hack team members
column11: but I don\'t see too much value in the change given the error is already pretty clear."'

column10: b'b" I think the option should be
column11: but I assume that isn\'t the issue given that it looks like it was compiling with jsonc.  The first issue seems to be caused by this url  not parsing the number as a double.  url  added this for the other parser.  The second one is because of your locale.  You should run in a shell using or similar:  "'

column10: b"b' This should be fixed in master with url  Comment if there are still issues.'"
b"b' Makes sense.  The fix is slightly off.  It needs to reparse the json string as a double
column11: because jsonc converts overflowing ints to INT_MIN or INT_MAX in its internal representation.  As is
column12: it is just casting it to a double.  It so happens that JSONC discards the original string
column13: so without reparsing the whole json blob
column14: it will be tough to fix this issue.  We can insert a warning easily.  The pecl extension using jsonc does not implement this properly either (for 8 byte longs
column15: and is even more messed up for 4 byte longs since it only has the correct behavior for numbers not overflowing a 8 byte int). url We should probably disable this test when running under jsonc.  Question is what behavior should this have?  Return INT_MAX? with INT_MAX?  Return the float conversion of INT_MAX (bleh)?'"
